You do not have to be good.
You do not have to walk on your knees
for a hundred miles through the desert repenting.
You only have to let the soft animal of your body
love what it loves.

"Wild Geese" opens with what might be the most generous five lines in modern poetry. Not a command, not a lesson — a release. "You do not have to be good." We expect poems to tell us to be better. Oliver starts by letting us off the hook entirely.

"You only have to let the soft animal of your body / love what it loves." This is not hedonism. It's something closer to trust. The soft animal of your body knows things. It knows what it's drawn to, what makes it come alive, what feels like home. And so much of life is spent overriding those signals in favor of what we think we should want.

The poem continues from here into a wider landscape — geese flying overhead, the world offering itself to your imagination — but these opening lines are where most people get stopped in their tracks. They carry the weight of permission, and permission, it turns out, is what many of us most desperately need.

This morning, consider: what does the soft animal of your body love? Not what should you love. Not what would be impressive to love. Just — what do you actually love?

I am living just as the century ends.

A great rain is coming. The fields are already wet.
I watch the valley from a window. The grasses
change their color as the year advances.

I am not young. And yet I feel young.
What is time? The leaves are blowing.
Life unrolls like an endless bolt of cloth.

Merwin writes without punctuation, as if even the pauses between thoughts are part of the same unbroken fabric. There are no full stops here — just as there are none in experience, not really. One moment flows into the next, the rain into the field, the year into the year.

What catches us is the plainness of his noticing. Grasses changing color. A window. A valley. He is not describing anything extraordinary, and that is precisely the point. The extraordinary is always already here, folded into the unremarkable texture of an afternoon. We just keep forgetting to look.

"I am not young. And yet I feel young." This is not denial or nostalgia — it is a different kind of attention. The body ages. The calendar turns. But something in us remains startled by existence, still watching the leaves blow as if for the first time. Merwin gives us permission to hold both truths at once: the weight of time passing and the lightness of being present within it.

Life unrolls like an endless bolt of cloth. We are somewhere in the middle of it, unable to see the whole pattern. And maybe that is enough — to feel the texture of this one stretch, right here, under our hands.

If the doors of perception were cleansed every thing would appear to man as it is, Infinite. For man has closed himself up, till he sees all things thro' narrow chinks of his cavern.
The Marriage of Heaven and Hell

Blake wrote these lines in the throes of revolution—French, American, industrial—when the old orders were cracking open. Yet his revolution was interior: a war against the dulling of the senses, against the way habit turns the miraculous into furniture.

What strikes me most is that word "cleansed." Not sharpened, not improved, not upgraded. Cleansed—as if our ordinary perception is already sufficient, merely obscured. We don't need new eyes; we need to wash the film from the ones we have. The infinite isn't hiding somewhere exotic. It's here, in the grain of the wooden table, in the steam rising from a cup, in the particular way light falls through a window this morning and will never fall quite the same way again.

The "narrow chinks" feel uncomfortably familiar. How much of any given day do we actually see? We navigate by category and assumption, by mental shorthand that gets us efficiently from task to task while the world streams past unwitnessed. This isn't a failing so much as a necessity—we'd be overwhelmed otherwise. But Blake is pointing to something we lose in the trade: the strangeness of existence itself, the raw fact that anything exists at all rather than nothing.

There's no technique offered here, no five-step program for cleansing perception. Perhaps the awareness alone is the beginning—noticing the cavern, feeling the narrowness of the chinks. Sometimes a single moment of genuine attention, a pause in the rushing, lets a sliver of the infinite leak through. The coffee tastes like something. The face across the table becomes, briefly, unfathomable. The world, for one breath, is new.
